description.narrative:
2030 Water Resources Group är ett unikt samarbete mellan offentliga, privata och civila organisationer. WRG faciliterar inkluderande och strukturerade processer genom sk nationella multi-stakeholders platforms i utvecklingsländer och tillväxtekonomier för att driva fram reformer och åtgärder inom vattenresursförvaltningen. I dessa plattformar ingår beslutsfattare, företag och representanter från civila samhället som katalyserar hållbara, rationella lösningar på vattenproblem. Målet är att stänga gapet mellan efterfrågan på vatten och tillgång till vatten innan år 2030.
WRG finansieras och styrs av IFC, som är värd för WRG, World Economic Forum, UNDP, IBRD, AfDB, ADB, Global Water Partnership, the Swiss agency for development and cooperation (SDC), Global Green Growth Institute och privata företag (Nestlé, PepsiCo, Coca Cola och Grundfos), Världsnaturfonden WWF och BRAC, en Bangladeshisk NGO med global verksamhet.
WRG arbetar för närvarande i åtta länder samt två indiska delstater; Bangladesh, Indien, Kenya, Tanzania, Mexiko, Mongoliet, Peru, Sydafrika, Karnataka och Mahrastra. De återupptar förnärvarande även sitt avbruta arbete i Jordanien.

Second phase of core support to Water Resources Group (WRG) a public-private-civil society partnership that helps governments to accelerate reforms for sustainable water resources management. WRG was initiated by World Economic Forum and is now hosted by IFC.

The ultimate goal of WRG is to reduce the water gap and to improve water resource management in the countries in which WRG operates as well as on a global scale. Intended outcomes from their work in respective country/state are:- Increase in coordinated and collaborative action to resolve water issues and strengthen water policies and governance, informed by appropriate data analytics- Preparatory arrangements for implementation of proposals formalised by third party- Projects, programs, policy reforms and financing mechanisms under implementation by third party- Investments into infrastructure and technologies by third party

description.narrative: Delivering on the ultimate goal of 2030 WRG to reduce the water gap and to improve water resource management, at an aggregated scale, 61 new projects, programs, policy reforms and financing mechanisms have been developed under the country-level Multi Stakeholder Platforms (MSPs). This has resulted in over 444 million USD of financing facilitated and approximately 385 million cubic meters/year less water being used. The later distributed on 152 million cubic meters less fresh water abstracted and 233 million cubic meters untreated waste/polluted water not being discharged. Furthermore an additional 14 000 cubic meters per year of water in increased cost-effective storage have been created. The model adopted by 2030 WRG of Analyse-Convene-Transform (ACT) has been tested in 14 countries and states with operational MSPs in 11 geographies with satisfactory result. 2030 WRG has acted as a catalyst delivering on the indented outcomes in different ways described below under each of the four stated outcomes: Increase in coordinated and collaborative action to resolve water issues and strengthen water policies and governance, informed by appropriate data analytics - Conducting hydro-economic analyses & research on critical water issues - Monitoring progress and resolving issues through MSP discussions A stakeholder survey was conducted in three countries (Mongolia, Bangladesh and Peru) in order to evaluate improvement in awareness levels connected to 2030 WRG activities. In general the survey showed a high level of awareness between 76-94 percent of the respondents. Preparatory arrangements for implementation of proposals formalised by third party - Convening government, private sector, & civil society in structured MSPs with an apex body, thematic workstreams, and time-bound task forces to support workstreams The number of proposals, as well as the value of budgets allocated or reallocated, for implementation by third party was 58 and USD 15 million respectively. Projects, programs, policy reforms and financing mechanisms under implementation by third party - Providing secretariat support to MSPs by developing concepts and proposals for implementation of solutions During the years 87 concept notes have been approved by MSP partnership to a funding value of 6.87 million USD. Investments into infrastructure and technologies by third party - Identifying third-party implementers and mobilizing financing for project implementation, including innovative financial mechanisms A total number of 642 partners from private, public and civil society participated in 46working groups that developed 66 final program proposals during the year. Of these, 61 is under implementation. Some examples over the years from the different regions are: Asia World’s largest community-based drip irrigation project at Ramthal in Karnataka covering 24,000 ha, with PPPs for micro irrigation and market linkages, part of a larger Drip-to-Market Agro Corridor approach to link drip irrigated areas with market opportunities. Water pollution fee guidelines, based on Polluter Pays principles with a new water pollution tariff, adopted by Government of Mongolia Africa Establishment of Kilimanjaro Water Stewardship Platform (KWSP) and Mount Kenya Ewaso Water Partnership (MKEWP) in Tanzania and Kenya as catchment level forums to mitigate conflicts over water resources and develop initiatives to address water security risks. Establishment of a Mine Water Coordinating Body (MWCB) in South Africa, bringing together companies, government and civil society and development and implementation of mine water for irrigation project pilot to reuse mine water for irrigation. Latin America Groundwater Management and Monitoring tariffs, Peru – a new levy, proposed and designed by 2030 WRG and validated by the MSP for implementation, is being raised by utilities in Lima and Trujillo from industrial groundwater users to protect aquifers in water stressed areas. Strengthening the planning and programming capabilities of the National Water Commission (CONAGUA), Mexico - 2030 WRG provided technical assistance to develop a prioritization system for capital investment in water infrastructure projects.
